feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 29 at 6:30AM EST by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
entry.summary: Areas of snow showers will affect the area through the morning. The more frequent snow showers will occur along the I-94 corridor from Chelsea to Ann Arbor to the down river communities of Wayne County. Temperatures have fallen into the upper 20s. Even though snow accumulations have been under an inch, roads are very slipper. Drivers should be prepared for slick roads and rapidly fluctuating visibilities in snow showers.
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 29 at 6:26AM EST by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
HAZARDS...A snow squall which can rapidly reduce visibility to less than one mile.
LOCATION AND MOVEMENT...At 626 AM EST, a snow squall was near DuBois moving east at 30 MPH.
THIS SQUALL WILL BE NEAR... S.B. Elliot State Park around 630 AM EST.
For those driving on Interstate 80, this includes areas between the Dubois and Snow Shoe exits, specifically from mile markers 97 to 141.
SAFETY INFO... Use extra caution if you must travel into or through this squall. Rapid changes in visibility and potentially slick roads may lead to accidents.
Conditions can deteriorate rapidly in winter weather situations. Be prepared for snow or ice covered roads. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.

cap:parameter.value: A SNOW SQUALL WILL AFFECT PARTS OF NORTHERN CENTRE...CAMERON... CLEARFIELD...AND ELK COUNTIES

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 29 at 3:20AM PST until December 1 at 1:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A moderate risk of sneaker waves is expected.
* WHERE...All beaches and shorelines of Douglas, Coos, and Curry counties.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY EVENING THROUGH SUNDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 29 at 5:16AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
At 516 AM EST, radar indicated an intense lake effect snow band over Geneva-On-The-Lake, moving east at 20 mph.
HAZARDS INCLUDE... Visibility rapidly dropping to less than a quarter of a mile... Up to 3 inches of quick snow accumulation...
Locations impacted include... Erie, Painesville, Ashtabula, Conneaut, Fairport Harbor, Geneva-On-The-Lake, Mentor, Edinboro, Geneva, Madison, Girard, North Kingsville, Cambridge Springs, Perry, Waterford, Albion, Northwest Harborcreek, Harborcreek, Mentor-On-The-Lake, and Lawrence Park.
Use extra caution if you must travel into or through this lake effect snow band. Rapid changes in visibility and potentially slick roads are likely to lead to accidents. Consider delaying travel until this snow band passes your location.
To report hazardous weather conditions, go to our website at weather.gov/cle and submit your report via social media, when you can do so safely.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake; Ashtabula Inland; Ashtabula Lakeshore; Northern Erie; Southern Erie; Crawford

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 29 at 1:57AM PST until December 2 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves from strong set behavior expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...In addition, an upcoming new moon will bring higher than usual tides and strong tidal swings. This can increase the chances of getting caught in quickly rising tides with a building swell. Higher tides will also increase wave washover on rocks and jetties.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

entry.summary:

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued November 29 at 3:48AM EST until November 30 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 10 and 28 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph, especially near the lakeshore.
* WHERE...Crawford, Northern Erie, and Southern Erie Counties.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Travel is impossible and should be postponed. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday morning and evening commutes and any post-holiday travel, especially along Interstates 90, 86, and 79.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hours are possible within the strongest lake effect bands. Lower snowfall totals are expected across the southern part of Crawford County. Winds will shift to the southwest on Saturday and push heavy snow away from the region for a period. Lake effect snow is likely to return across the area on Sunday into early next week and bring additional snowfall. Additional winter weather headlines may be needed to address this next round of snow.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM EST SATURDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued November 29 at 3:48AM EST until November 30 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:

entry.summary:
...SNOW POTENTIAL CONTINUES THROUGH THIS WEEKEND...
.Snow continues through tonight for the Hyder area.
An additional round of heavy snow is forecasted for this weekend as warm moist air moves over the Panhandle starting Friday night. Expect snow to spread north through Saturday into Sunday, with the potential to see near a foot of snow along the Icy Strait Corridor and Hyder. The Central Panhandle will also likely receive a range of 3 to 6 inches of snow Saturday into Sunday.
Expect a transition to rainfall starting Saturday night for the southern Panhandle with rain expected along the Icy Strait corridor by Monday afternoon.

* WHEN...For the Winter Storm Warning, until 6 AM AKST Friday. For the Winter Storm Watch, from Saturday afternoon through late Sunday night.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 3:07PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
System details: Friday night an approaching system will feature deep moisture, driving 1 to 2 inches of snow through Saturday until warmer air at the surface arrives and a transition to all rain occurs overnight Saturday. As rainfall continues Sunday, 24 hour rainfall totals will be around 2 to 4 inches.
Timing: Snow starts near 10pm Friday night, continues to near 10pm Saturday evening.
24-hour snow totals: The current forecast takes a modest approach and falls in line with most model guidance means; highlighting a general 1 to 2 inches of wet and heavy snowfall in 24 hours. With that said, we will see locally higher amounts along elevated portions of the PoW road system. If QPF totals and snowfall rates surpass current forecast expectations, we could receive 3 to 5 inches.
Sleet/freezing rain potential: There also exists the potential for a few hours of sleet/freezing rain as snow transitions to rain Saturday night.
Confidence: High on timing. Low on 24 hour snow totals. Low on sleet/freezing rain.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: POTENTIAL FOR SNOW FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued November 27 at 3:17PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
SABCO
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...A SPECIAL AVALANCHE ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4:30 PM WEDNESDAY UNTIL 4:30 PM SUNDAY...
*WHAT...Avalanche conditions are more dangerous than weve experienced this season. *WHERE...All mountainous areas in Colorado *WHEN... From 4:30 PM Wednesday until 4:30 PM Sunday. *IMPACTS... Backcountry travelers can easily trigger dangerous avalanches large enough to injure or kill a human. *PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Avoid traveling on and under slopes with a slope angle steeper than about 30 degrees. You can trigger avalanches from a distance or from below. We will update the avalanche forecast each afternoon with more detailed information on local areas. Check it at www.colorado.gov/avalanche.
Davis
